1) Meat preparation:
 - Choose chilled meat with little blood and a fresh smell (pork or beef). Trim excess membranes but leave some fat — it adds flavor and protects during drying.
 2) Dry salting (method similar to your own):
 - Put a thin layer of salt in the bottom of a clean food-safe container (use a mix of regular salt and curing/nitrite salt if the recipe calls for it — see warnings).
 - Place the piece of meat and completely cover it with the salt mixture (about 2–3% of the meat weight in total salt mix; for 1 kg of meat this is roughly 25–30 g of ordinary salt; if you use nitrite salt, reduce the amount of ordinary salt accordingly).
 - Leave in the refrigerator (+4…+8°C) for 4–6 days. A lot of liquid is released during the first 1–2 days — drain it, pat the meat dry and replace the salt if necessary. From day 3–6 less liquid appears — check firmness and salt penetration.
 3) Drying and spices:
 - Remove the meat, quickly rinse off excess salt if needed, and pat dry with a towel.
 - Rub in dry spices (pepper, garlic, coriander, etc.). Wrap in parchment paper or breathable cloth and tie with butcher's twine.
 - Note: change the parchment/cloth during the first 2–3 days to prevent local wet spots and mold.
 4) Drying/curing:
 - Place on a curing rack in a refrigerator or curing chamber at +4…+8°C with relative humidity of 70–85%.
 - Drying takes 14–20 days depending on the thickness of the cut and desired dryness.
 5) Checks and doneness:
 - Check aroma (should be pleasant, "meaty", no rotten smell) and surface — a light white bloom (beneficial mold) is acceptable, but green or black mold is not. Slice a test piece to check taste and texture.
 6) Storage:
 - Store in the refrigerator (vacuum-packed or tightly wrapped) up to 2 months; vacuum-packed up to 6 months at stable temperature.
 7) Warnings:
 - Curing (nitrite) salt helps protect against botulism in wet or improper conditions, but excessive use is dangerous — follow dosages exactly. For home use, use nitrite salt only in tested recipes and correct amounts, or use commercial curing mixes / starter cultures.
 - Strict hygiene, refrigeration and temperature control are key to safety.

1) Preparation and salting:
 - Choose a piece of pork (or a mix), trim large membranes. Calculate salt: a combination of nitrite and regular salt according to the recipe (follow the nitrite salt package instructions precisely).
 - Rub the meat evenly with the salt and dry spice mixture (smoked paprika, coriander, garlic). Place in a container and keep at +4…+8°C for 48 hours.
 2) Rinse / spices:
 - After the salting time, rinse and dry if necessary, then coat with an additional spice mix to boost aroma.
 3) Curing/drying:
 - Dry at +4…+8°C, humidity 70–85%, for 14–20 days. For extra pungency you can do a short maturation stage at slightly higher temperature (+8…+10°C) for the first 2–3 days.
 4) Checks:
 - Inspect surface and smell; change parchment as needed.
 5) Storage:
 - Refrigerate for up to 3 months; vacuum-packed up to 6 months.
 6) Safety note:
 - Nitrites help prevent botulism but are toxic at high doses. Do not exceed recommended amounts.

1) Ingredient selection:
 - Ratio: about 70% lean meat + 30% fat (for traditional dry sausages). Use fresh chilled cuts of pork and/or beef.
 2) Grinding and mixing:
 - Chill meat and fat to ~2–6°C for easier processing.
 - Grind through a coarse plate first, then a finer plate for uniform texture, or use a food processor.
 - Add salt (regular + nitrite if the recipe calls for it), spices, garlic and, optionally, starter culture (lactic acid bacteria) — starter cultures improve fermentation stability and safety.
 - Mix thoroughly until salt and spices are evenly distributed. Keep the mince temperature below 10°C (preferably 4–8°C).
 3) Stuffing into casings:
 - Stuff the mince into natural or collagen casings of the desired diameter. Remove air pockets and tie the ends.
 4) Fermentation (critical step):
 - Place the sausages in a fermentation chamber at +18…+24°C and relative humidity 85–95% for 24–72 hours (time depends on the culture and desired acidity). During this time pH drops — important for flavor and safety.
 - If using a starter culture, follow the manufacturer's instructions for temperature and timing.
 5) Drying/curing:
 - After fermentation move to a chamber with lower temperature +10…+14°C and humidity 70–85%.
 - Drying takes from 2 to 6 weeks depending on casing diameter and target final moisture. Check weight and appearance periodically.
 6) External care:
 - A white surface coating (beneficial mold) may develop — this is normal. Remove and clean areas with black/green mold using a mild salt solution.
 7) Storage:
 - When desired dryness is reached, store in the fridge or a cool place; in vacuum packaging they can last several months. Monitor smell and appearance.
 8) Warnings:
 - Follow the temperature profile: warm fermentation (+18…+24°C) is crucial to reach correct acidity; then dry at lower temperatures.
 - For beginners, use tested recipes with starter cultures and precise measurements for salt and nitrites.

1) Ingredients and preparation:
 - Malt, hops, water and yeast are the main components. Calculate original gravity (OG) according to the recipe.
 2) Mash:
 - Heat water to mash temperature (typically 62–68°C depending on desired body) and hold for 60–90 minutes to extract fermentable sugars. Keep the temperature stable.
 3) Lauter / sparge:
 - Separate wort from the grain and rinse with hot water (72–78°C) to recover remaining sugars.
 4) Boil:
 - Boil the wort for 60–90 minutes, adding hops according to the schedule for bitterness, flavor and preservation. Watch for boilovers and hot break.
 5) Cooling and pitching:
 - Rapidly cool the wort to fermentation temperature (typically +18–22°C for ales, +8–12°C for lagers) and transfer to the fermenter.
 - Pitch the yeast. Aerate the wort before pitching to support yeast health.
 6) Primary fermentation:
 - Hold at a stable temperature for 5–14 days (depends on yeast strain). Monitor activity (krausen, drop in gravity).
 7) Conditioning / maturation:
 - Transfer to a secondary fermenter for conditioning at a lower temperature for 7–14 days or longer for a cleaner profile.
 8) Bottling / carbonation:
 - Bottle with priming sugar for natural carbonation or keg and force-carbonate. When bottling, monitor sugar dose and sanitation — overactive secondary fermentation can cause bottle failure.
 9) Storage:
 - Condition in bottles/kegs at +4°C for several weeks to months. Shelf life depends on the style — typically up to 6 months for stable flavor.
 10) Safety note:
 - When bottle-conditioning, use correct sugar amounts and good sanitation to avoid excessive pressure.

1) Raw material preparation:
 - Select healthy grapes and remove rotten berries. Washing is optional; handle in clean equipment.
 2) Crushing / pressing:
 - Crush grapes to release juice (press before fermentation for white wines; ferment on skins for reds).
 3) Must preparation and yeast addition:
 - Measure sugar and acidity; adjust if necessary (add sugar or acid as needed).
 - Prepare the must and pitch selected wine yeast.
 4) Primary fermentation:
 - Ferment at controlled temperatures: usually +18–25°C for reds, +12–18°C for whites. Duration 5–14 days depending on variety and temperature.
 5) Separation of solids / pressing (for reds):
 - After active fermentation separate the wine from the skins and transfer to a secondary vessel.
 6) Secondary fermentation and aging:
 - Age in barrels/demijohns at lower temperatures; the period may be weeks to months or years depending on style.
 7) Stabilization and bottling:
 - Rack off lees, stabilize as needed and, if required, add a small measured dose of SO2 (sulfites) for preservation — follow instructions and measure accurately.
 8) Storage:
 - Store bottles at stable temperature (typically +10–14°C) and horizontally for corked closures. Aging times depend on the grape and style — from months to years.
 9) Warnings:
 - Sanitation and correct sulfite dosing are important; if unsure, follow tested step-by-step guides and use proper equipment.

1) Bread preparation (infusion/soaking):
 - Use rye bread (toasted breadcrumbs or crusts). For 5 L of water usually 300–500 g of bread.
 - Pour hot (not boiling) water over the bread (~80°C) and let it steep for 6–12 hours (your 18-hour reference is also acceptable for a stronger infusion).
 2) Straining and sweetening:
 - Strain the infusion, add sugar (amount per recipe, e.g. 100–200 g per 5 L depending on desired sweetness) and cool to 20–30°C.
 3) Adding yeast:
 - Add a small amount of dry yeast (5–7 g per 5 L) or leave for spontaneous fermentation (longer and less predictable).
 4) Fermentation:
 - Keep at room temperature (+18–24°C) for 1–3 days until noticeable fermentation occurs (depends on yeast and temperature). Your 3.5 days is a typical total time to reach desired acidity and carbonation.
 5) Settling and bottling:
 - Strain and transfer to bottles. For light carbonation, add a little sugar at bottling. Monitor pressure — store cold to slow fermentation.
 6) Storage:
 - In the refrigerator — up to 5 days for peak freshness; flavor will change over longer storage.
 7) Warnings:
 - When carbonating in bottles watch pressure — use strong bottles and reasonable sugar amounts.

1) Preparing and salting the cabbage:
 - Break napa cabbage into leaves or pieces, sprinkle with salt (about 2–3% of weight) and leave for 2–6 hours, turning occasionally to help brine form.
 2) Rinsing and pressing:
 - Rinse leaves to remove excess salt and lightly press, leaving enough salt for fermentation.
 3) Preparing the paste/filling:
 - Chop garlic, ginger and chili; mix with fish sauce/shrimp paste and a little sugar to taste; add carrots/daikon if desired.
 4) Packing:
 - Rub the paste between the leaves thoroughly and pack tightly into a jar or container to eliminate air pockets. Keep the vegetables submerged under brine (use a weight or container of water on top).
 5) Fermentation:
 - Leave at room temperature (+18–22°C) for 2–7 days (depending on desired sourness). Your 5–6 day note is a normal range. Taste daily to track progress.
 6) Storage:
 - Once desired fermentation is reached, refrigerate — keeps up to 2 months and will develop flavor slowly.
 7) Warnings:
 - Ensure ingredients remain under brine; if unpleasant smells or unusual mold appear, discard the batch.

1) Preparation and salting:
 - Shred cabbage thinly, sprinkle with salt (about 2% of cabbage weight — 20 g per 1 kg) and mix thoroughly until juice is released.
 2) Packing and pressing:
 - Pack the cabbage tightly into a clean jar or crock, pressing firmly so the released juice covers it. Use a weight or a container of water to apply pressure.
 3) Fermentation:
 - Keep at +16–22°C for 7–14 days for active fermentation; then move to +10–16°C for slow maturation for several more weeks (your 10 days at +18°C is a suitable baseline).
 4) Checks and storage:
 - When flavor and acidity are right, transfer to cold storage (+2–6°C). In the fridge sauerkraut keeps well — up to 6 months.
 5) Warnings:
 - The cabbage must remain submerged in brine; white benign scum on the surface is normal, but green or black mold is not.
